questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with increased fatiguability and shortness of breath.  He would feel tired after exercise or activity and would feel better after rest or on waking up in the morning.  Investigations reveal the presence of anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. Which of the following pulmonary flow-volume loops would most likely correspond to the disease he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient with antibodies against acetylcholine receptors is myasthenia gravis. His pulmonary function test is likely to show a restrictive pattern corresponding to curve D.   

Myasthenia gravis presents with ventilatory restriction due to reduced respiratory muscle strength and shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by decreased total lung capacity and vital capacity. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts toward the right, as seen in Curve D in comparison to Curve A, which represents the normal flow-volume curve.

Curve B represents an obstructive pattern of the flow-volume curve in which the expiratory limb is concave upward. This is also called a scooped-out or coved pattern and is observed in conditions responsible for airflow obstruction, like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 

Tracheal stenosis shows a fixed upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve, as seen in curve C. In this condition, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of an elderly male patient with bilateral pitting pedal edema, a 3.7 cm rise of jugulovenous pulse is noted on gentle compression with the palm over the abdomen for about 30 seconds. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
This sign is called positive hepatojugular reflux.

It is elicited by applying firm pressure over the liver for 15 to 30 seconds while observing the neck veins for increasing jugular venous pressure (JVP). This reflux indicates that the right ventricle cannot accommodate the increase in venous pressure.  

This sign is positive in right heart failure and severe tricuspid regurgitation. Additionally, there are prominent V waves and Y descent in tricuspid regurgitation.

JVP is measured as the distance between the top of jugular venous pulsation and the sternal angle of Louis. The normal height of JVP is between 6 cm to 8 cm H2O. 

Other options:

Option A - A large pericardial effusion can compress the base of the left lung. This is noted as Ewart's sign - an area of dullness and increased fremitus beneath the angle of the left scapula. 

Option C & D - Friedrich's sign and Kussmaul's sign are both seen in constrictive pericarditis. Friedreich's sign is the prominent y descent of the jugular venous waveform, and Kussmaul's sign is the rise (or lack of fall) of JVP with inspiration.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presented with complaints of easy fatigability. Laboratory findings revealed anaemia, hypercalcemia, and an elevated ESR. Urinalysis indicated the presence of Bence-Jones proteins. Which of the following tests is most accurate for diagnosing the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presentations of easy fatigability, anaemia, hypercalcemia, elevated ESR, and Bence-Jones proteins on urinalysis suggest multiple myeloma. The most accurate test for diagnosing multiple myeloma is bone marrow biopsy.

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy in which there is an increased proliferation of monoclonal plasma cells. There is an increased production of monoclonal paraprotein (M protein). 

Clinical features of multiple myeloma:

  1. Bone pain (most common): Due to the proliferation of tumour cells, activation of osteoclasts that destroy bone, and suppression of osteoblasts that form new bone. Persistent localized pain in a patient with myeloma usually signifies a pathological fracture.
  2. Fever due to recurrent bacterial infections (second most common)
  3. Acute kidney injury due to:  Hypercalcemia (most common), amyloid deposits, hyperuricemia, recurrent infections, infiltration of the kidney by myeloma cells
  4. Normocytic-normochromic anaemia due to the replacement of normal marrow by expanding tumour cells
    Inhibition of hematopoiesis by factors made by the tumor
    Reduced production of erythropoietin by the kidney

Other options

Option B: Serum protein electrophoresis is the initial investigation, but bone marrow biopsy is more accurate. Serum protein electrophoresis shows the presence of monoclonal protein.

Option C: Peripheral smear shows rouleaux formation, and also is suggestive of normocytic and normochromic anaemia, but is not a diagnostic test for multiple myeloma.

Option D: CT scan detects lytic bone lesions associated with multiple myeloma, but it is not a primary diagnostic test for multiple myeloma. Imaging is supportive, and not diagnostic.

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypertensive man presents with a dry cough and severe chest pain. Two months ago, he had an inferior wall myocardial infarction and was treated with stenting of the right coronary artery. He is febrile and hemodynamically stable, and cardiac examination shows a high-pitched scratching sound. The ECG is shown below. The troponin I level is 0.2 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-myocardial infarction (MI) patient presenting with pleuritic chest pain, fever, malaise, pericardial rub on auscultation, and the ECG given above showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with upward concavity are suggestive of postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome).

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome), a type of postcardiac injury syndrome, usually occurs 1–6 weeks after MI due to immune-complex mediated damage in the pericardium. Patients typically present with features of acute pericarditis such as fever, tachypnea, chest pain that is worse during inspiration and lying down, a pericardial rub, increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST elevations on ECG. Dressler syndrome may also cause pericardial effusion.

Treatment:

  • First-line therapy consists of high-dose aspirin
  • Colchicine enhances the response to NSAIDs and prevents recurrence in patients with severe disease.
Other complications of Myocardial infarction
  1. Myocardial rupture
  2. Contractile dysfunction
  3. Arrhythmia:
    • Ventricular fibrillation is the most common arrhythmia within the first 24 hours of MI
    • Supraventricular tachycardia
    • Heart block
  4. Pericarditis: occur even 48 hrs after MI
  5. Dressler syndrome or post-MI syndrome: usually 2–3 weeks after a transmural MI
  6. Ventricular aneurysm
  7. Progressive late heart failure (chronic IHD)
  8. Infarct expansion associated with mural thrombus
  9. Papillary muscle dysfunction

Option A: Ventricular aneurysm occurs weeks to months after an MI and presents with congestive heart failure, arterial embolisms, or ventricular arrhythmias. They present with a double diffuse apical pulse on examination due to apical aneurysms.

Option C: Cardiac wall rupture results in cardiac tamponade. Patients with cardiac tamponade would have features such as dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, pulsus paradoxus, and increased jugular venous pressure, unlike this patient, who is hemodynamically stable.

Option D: Pulmonary embolism may present with cough, low-grade fever, chest pain, and ST elevations, but patients would also have hemodynamic instability, risk factors of immobility, or clinical features of deep vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with a history of high-grade fever for the last 5 days. She was recently diagnosed with a ventricular septal defect. On examination, a new regurgitant murmur is heard and an echocardiogram shows the presence of a mass on the mitral valve. When her hands were examined, the following lesions were seen which were painful. What are these lesions known as?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient would be infective endocarditis (IE). The image shows erythematous, nodular lesions located in the pads of the fingers which are painful. These are known as Osler nodes. It occurs due to immune complex deposition and vasculitis.

Patients with infective endocarditis can have cardiac or non-cardiac manifestations.

Cardiac manifestations of IE:

  • Presence of new regurgitant murmurs
  • Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction
  • Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae- This is caused due to the extension of infection beyond the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue
  • Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess.
  • Embolization of coronary arteries

Noncardiac manifestations of IE are:

  • Arterial emboli- causing pain of ischemia of the organs
  • Osler's nodes -are painful, red, nodular lesions usually located in the pads of the fingers and toes
  • Roth's spots- retinal hemorrhages with a pale center
  • Janeway lesions- In contrast to Osler's nodes, these are faint, red, painless macules on palms and soles. They occur as a result of septic embolization and are commonly associated with staphylococcal IE.
  • Splenic abscess
  • Cerebral abscess
  • Immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis
  • Positivity for rheumatoid factor
  • Petechiae on oral and conjunctival mucosa
  • Splinter subungual hemorrhages-painless, dark red lines in the nailbed.
  • Mycotic aneurysms
  • Splenomegaly

Below image- Janeway lesions (Option A)

Below image- Roth Spots (Option C)

The Woronoff ring (Option D) is the clear peripheral zone around the plaques, seen in psoriasis.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss and ascites. A radiograph of the chest is shown below. Which of the following would not be found in ascitic fluid analysis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of tuberculous peritonitis secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. Paracentesis would reveal an exudate with high protein content and, therefore, a SAAG of <1.1g/L.

This patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss, and a radiograph showing a homogenous dense infiltrate in the right lung is consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). The presence of ascites and the above-mentioned signs and symptoms suggest tuberculous peritonitis.   

The various pathogenic mechanisms of gastrointestinal TB include direct seeding into the abdomen due to swallowing of the sputum, hematogenous seeding of tubercle bacilli from rupture of lymph nodes or intraabdominal organs, and ingestion of milk from cows infected with bovine TB. It presents with abdominal pain, swelling, obstruction, hematochezia, and a palpable abdominal mass. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, night sweats, and anorexia are also present. The terminal ileum and cecum are the most commonly involved sites. 

The presence of fever, abdominal pain, and ascites should raise the suspicion of tuberculous peritonitis. The clinical presentation may be similar to Crohn's disease if the intestinal wall is involved, leading to ulcerations and fistulae. 

Paracentesis reveals an exudate with high protein content, lymphocytosis, and elevated levels of adenosine deaminase (ADA). Elevated ADA levels have very high sensitivity for tuberculous peritonitis. Standard anti-tubercular therapy is recommended for ascites caused by tuberculous peritonitis. If the etiology of the ascites is uncertain, laparoscopy with peritoneal biopsy for culture and histology remains the gold standard.

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital conditions is most commonly associated with the arrhythmia given in the ECG?
questions.solution:
The ECG depicts Wolff Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome, which is due to the accessory pathway and is most commonly associated with Ebstein’s anomaly. 

Wolf Parkinson White (WPW) is a type of preexcitation syndrome, i.e., abnormally early ventricular excitation, which, in WPW, occurs via a bypass tract (Bundle of Kent). Normally, there is a normal AV nodal delay to allow adequate ventricular filling. The bypass tract allows impulses to skip the nodal delay, leading to preexcitation of the ventricles. In this syndrome, there is both preexcitation and delayed conduction, leading to a shortened PR interval (< 0.12 secs) and wide QRS. There is a characteristic delta wave notch in the QRS wave, as seen in the picture.

Accessory pathways (APs) are abnormal conduction pathways connecting the atrium and ventricle. They can conduct impulses in the following ways:

  • Antegrade conduction: Examples- WPW syndrome and antidromic AVRT
  • Retrograde conduction: Examples - concealed accessory pathways (can cause SVTs) and orthodromic AVRT.

Accessory pathways are associated with Ebstein’s anomaly of the tricuspid valve and forms of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, including PRKAG2 mutations, Danon’s disease, and Fabry’s disease.

Patent ductus arteriosus, Arterial septal defect and Tetralogy of Fallot are rarely associated with WPW syndrome.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman was diagnosed with chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura 12 months back. She was on corticosteroids and now presents with features shown in the image after the glucocorticoids are tapered. Her platelet count is 6000/μL. What is the next appropriate step of management in this case?
questions.solution:
The next appropriate step in the management in this case is splenectomy.

The given image shows petechiae of the oral mucosa. The appearance of such lesions after more than a month of glucocorticoid treatment in an individual who is diagnosed with immune thrombocytopenic purpura suggests a relapse. Splenectomy is used for the treatment of patients who relapse after glucocorticoids are tapered.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder characterized by immune-mediated destruction of platelets and possibly inhibition of platelet release from the megakaryocyte. Secondary causes of ITP are:

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • HIV-AIDS
  • Hepatitis C.

ITP usually presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, very low platelet count, and normal peripheral blood cells. Patients usually present either with ecchymoses and petechiae or with thrombocytopenia incidentally found on a routine blood test. Mucocutaneous bleeding, such as oral mucosa, gastrointestinal, or heavy menstrual bleeding, may be present.

Rarely, life-threatening, including the central nervous system, bleeding can occur. Blood blisters in the mouth and retinal haemorrhages may herald life-threatening bleeding.

Management of ITP:

  • In patients with platelet counts >30,000/μL, treatment may be instituted if there are symptoms of life-threatening bleeding.
  • Prednisone at 1 mg/kg is the initial treatment of choice.
  • Rh(D) immune globulin is used only in Rh-positive patients.
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG).
  • Splenectomy is indicated in patients who have relapsed on glucocorticoid therapy. Relapse patients with intermittent or high platelet count can be managed with anti-Rh0(D) immunoglobulin, IVIG, or with a thrombopoietin receptor antagonist.
  • Subcutaneous romiplostim and oral eltrombopag are thrombopoietin receptor agonists used in adults who are at risk of bleeding even after splenectomy.

questions.text:
In VAP patients infected with high-MIC isolates of MRSA, with pre-existing renal disorder, which of the following is the preferred drug used in managing this condition?

VAP - Ventilator-associated pneumonia 

MIC - Minimum inhibitory concentration

MRSA - Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus
questions.solution:
The preferred drug for managing VAP in patients infected with high-MIC isolates of MRSA with pre-existing renal disorder is Linezolid.

In MRSA infections with high MICs to vancomycin (e.g., ≥2 µg/mL), vancomycin (option A)  may be less effective due to reduced efficacy in eradicating MRSA with higher MICs. Higher doses of vancomycin would typically be required, but this increases the risk of nephrotoxicity, as it is primarily cleared by the kidneys.  In patients with pre-existing renal disease, using vancomycin can further worsen renal function.

Linezolid is effective against MRSA and has excellent lung penetration, making it a suitable choice for treating VAP caused by MRSA. Unlike vancomycin, linezolid is metabolized by the liver, so it does not carry the same risks of nephrotoxicity in patients with renal impairment. This makes it a safer option for patients with renal disorders. 

Other options:

Cefepime (option C) is a cephalosporin that is ineffective against MRSA and would not be appropriate for MRSA infections. Tobramycin (option D) is an aminoglycoside that also lacks efficacy against MRSA and carries a significant risk of nephrotoxicity, which would be unsuitable for a patient with renal impairment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with a history of chronic abdominal pain, diarrhea, low-grade fever, weight loss, and fatigue. She underwent a colonoscopy which revealed a cobble-stone appearance. Which of the following type of renal stones is most commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, cobblestone appearance on colonoscopy is suggestive of Crohn's disease. Calcium oxalate stones are more commonly associated with Crohn's disease. 

In Crohn's disease, fatty acids are not absorbed because of ileal dysfunction. These fatty acids in the gut lumen bind to calcium. Because of this, the dietary oxalates which normally bind to calcium are now left unbound. This leads to increased absorption of dietary oxalates causing hyperoxaluria and oxalate stones.

Clinical features of Crohn's disease:

Cardinal manifestations

  • Crampy abdominal pain may be limited to the right lower quadrant in patients with ileal disease.
  • Intermittent and persistent diarrhea: Fluid secretion/impaired absorption in the inflamed bowel, bile acid malabsorption, steatorrhea due to loss of bile salts, and enteroenteric fistulas.
  • Fatigue
  • Fistulae and abscesses
  • Malabsorption

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Arthritis and arthropathy
  • Uveitis, iritis and episcleritis
  • Erythema nodosum and pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Secondary amyloidosis
  • Renal stones: Calcium oxalate stones
  • Bone loss
  • Pulmonary involvement: Bronchiectasis, chronic bronchitis, ILD, BOOP, sarcoidosis.

 Gross features of Crohn's disease include:

  • Aphthous ulcers
  • Longitudinal ulcers
  • Skip lesions
  • Creeping fat
  • Cobblestone appearance

Microscopically aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses are the earliest lesions. There is transmural inflammation. Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of affected organs Other histologic features of CD include submucosal or subserosal lymphoid aggregates, microscopic skip areas, and pseudo pyloric metaplasia

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with diarrhea and weight loss. On examination, the height and weight are lesser than expected. Laboratory investigations were positive for class II HLA-DQ2. Which of the following will you advise the child?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and growth retardation, along with positive class II HLA-DQ2, is consistent with a diagnosis of celiac disease. Patients with celiac disease are advised to avoid gluten.

Celiac disease, also known as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy, is an immune-mediated disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing foods such as wheat, rye, or barley in genetically predisposed individuals.

The histopathology is characterized by increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy. This loss of mucosal and brush-border surface area contributes to malabsorption.

The diagnosis in patients with positive antibodies is confirmed by biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presents with neurologic symptoms and visual disturbances. He has a history of a painless ulcer on his penis that resolved on its own 15 years ago. What other symptoms are likely to be concomitantly present?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has acquired syphilis due to unprotected sex and has developed neurological and visual disturbances secondarily as a complication of neurosyphilis, which can be complicated by the concomitant presence of saccular aortic aneurysms.

Neurosyphilis is the third stage of syphilis and also has other features like cardiovascular syphilis, which occurs due to inflammation and occlusion of the vasa vasorum of the aorta, leading to the characteristic tree bark aortitis and aneurysms. These foci of inflammation are triggered by the spirochetes in the blood vessel walls. 
Stages of syphilis:

  • Primary chancre: Painless, indurated, button-like ulcer with painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Secondary syphilis is the stage when generalised manifestations of syphilis appear on the skin and mucous membranes. A macular rash is commonly seen, and this stage may be preceded by constitutional symptoms such as fever, sore throat, and malaise.
  • Latent syphilis is the stage when there are no clinical features of the active disease, but serological testing for the disease is positive.  
  • Late syphilis (tertiary syphilis) commonly presents as superficial or nodular punched-out ulcers or gummas (granulomas appearing as cutaneous plaques or nodules with central ulceration) that appear 3-10 years after infection. It may also present as red nodules (nodular syphilides), neurosyphilis, and cardiovascular syphilis. 

Serological testing is done using standard non-treponemal antibody tests like VDRL and rapid plasma reagin (RPR). Specific treponemal antibody tests like Treponema pallidum hemagglutination assay (TPHA) and fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) are further required. Microscopically, T. palladium is identified with characteristic corkscrew morphology and motility on darkfield microscopy. Parenteral penicillin G is the drug of choice for all stages of syphilis. Treatment of recent sexual contacts is recommended. 

Other Options:

Option A: Maculopapular rash is a manifestation of secondary syphilis.

Option C: Painless lymphadenopathy is seen in the inguinal region in primary syphilis and not in tertiary syphilis

Option D: Petechial haemorrhages are not known manifestations of syphilis.

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A patient undergoes upper GI endoscopy, which reveals characteristic longitudinal furrows, multiple esophageal rings, whitish exudate, and loss of vascular markings. What is the cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
The characteristic upper GI endoscopic findings of multiple esophageal rings, longitudinal furrows, whitish exudate and loss of vascular markings (edema) are seen in Eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal 1/3rd of the esophagus. Eosinophils migrate to the esophagus and contribute to extensive tissue damage and inflammation.  

Clinical features include difficulty in swallowing, food impaction, vomiting, heartburn, and symptoms similar to those of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It is usually non-responsive to PPI therapy. 

On endoscopy, the esophagus appears narrow and friable with transient or fixed mucosal rings, strictures, linear furrows, and whitish exudate. Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus. These rings appear similar to stripes on a cat, and the appearance is referred to as the feline esophagus sign. It is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae, with the resultant shortening of the esophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen. The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per high-power field.

First-line therapies include proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), elimination diets and swallowed topical corticosteroids (STCs).

Other options:

Option A: Candida esophagitis is characterized by adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes composed of densely matted fungal hyphae and inflammatory cells covering the oesophagal mucosa.

Option C: Corrosive esophagitis may lead to oesophagal perforation, bleeding, strictures, and death.

Option D: In Radiation esophagitis, the oesophagal mucosa becomes erythematous, edematous, and friable. Submucosal fibrosis and degenerative tissue changes and stricturing occur years after radiation exposure.

questions.text: A 73-year-old male patient diagnosed with a history of asymptomatic chronic lymphocytic leukemia presents with episodes of night sweats, diffuse cervical lymphadenopathy, and weight loss for 3 weeks. Chest X-ray is clear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of asymptomatic chronic lymphocytic leukemia now has new onset symptoms of night sweats, lymphadenopathy, and weight loss. This is most likely a result of the transformation of the CLL to Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (Richter Transformation).

Richter's syndrome is the transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) to aggressive lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL). It has a poor prognosis. Patients develop the following features:

  • Fever and weight loss
  • Rapidly enlarging lymph nodes 
  • Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase 

DLBCL is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is characteristic of large cell types and shows a diffuse pattern of growth. The most frequent pathological abnormality seen is dysregulation of BCL6.

Mature B-cell tumours express CD19 and CD20 markers. Special subtypes of DLBCL include immunodeficiency-associated large B-cell lymphoma and primary effusion lymphoma.

Other options:

Option A: Reactivated tuberculosis can present with night sweats, weight loss, and cough. However, there is no finding on the chest X-ray. In this patient with a known history of CLL, DLBCL is more likely.

Option C: Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalised lymphadenopathy, which has a slow progression. This patient's symptoms are more suggestive of a more rapidly progressive condition like DLBCL.

Option D: Burkitt’s lymphoma is an aggressive type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) that mainly occurs in children and young adults. It usually presents with a mass involving the mandible and abdominal viscera. This patient with a history of CLL most likely has DLBCL.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with sudden onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. On examination, he was found to be tachycardic. An ECG was performed, which showed the S1Q3T3 sign. A chest x-ray was also done. Which of the following signs would not be found on the chest x-ray in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of pulmonary embolism. The black pleura sign would not be found on the chest x-ray of this patient.

The black pleura sign is seen in alveolar pulmonary microlithiasis. It refers to the shadow of the pleura between the extensive alveolar calcification and the adjacent rib cage.

Other options: Westermark's sign, Palla’s sign, and Hampton's hump are the signs found on the chest x-ray of pulmonary embolism.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: All of the following favour a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Painless diarrhoea or constipation does not favour the diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterised by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Since there is no specific diagnostic marker for IBS, the diagnosis is based on Rome IV criteria, which include the clinical manifestations of the disease. Abdominal pain is an anchor feature of IBS. It should be associated (improvement or worsening) with defecation or with a change in the frequency or form of stool. Painless diarrhoea or constipation does not fulfil the criteria to be diagnosed as IBS. The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of IBS.

The extent of the diagnostic evaluation of a patient suspected to have IBS depends on the possibility of an organic disorder in that patient. A complete blood count and a sigmoidoscopy should be done for most patients. In addition, stool samples should be examined for ova and parasites in patients who have diarrhoea-predominant IBS. The mainstay of treatment for IBS is a diet low in fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols (FODMAPs). Pharmacotherapy consists of Alosetron (5-HT3 antagonist) or Loperamide for diarrhoea-predominant IBS and psyllium husk, lactulose, Lubiprostone, and Prucalopride (5-HT4 agonist) for constipation-predominant IBS. Peppermint oil is effective in improving abdominal pain associated with IBS, but probiotics have shown no benefit.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: You are reviewing a young female in the Intensive Care Unit who came with complaints of ascending paralysis. Guillian-Barré syndrome (GBS) was suspected. Now you notice that she has developed difficulty in breathing.  Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows very low pO2 and high pCO2 levels. What is the type of respiratory failure seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of Guillian-Barré syndrome(GBS) with hypoxemia and hypercapnia is suggestive of type 2 respiratory failure. 

Type II respiratory failure occurs as a consequence of alveolar hypoventilation and results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. The mechanism of type II respiratory failure in Guillian-Barré syndrome can be due to impaired neuromuscular transmission.

Reduced strength for respiration can be due to impaired neuromuscular transmission (e.g., myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) or respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., myopathy, electrolyte derangements, fatigue) or diminished CNS drive to breathe (Drug overdose, brainstem injury, sleep-disordered breathing, and severe hypothyroidism).

Treatment:

  • Reversing the underlying causes of ventilatory failure
  • Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation with a tight-fitting facial or nasal mask (avoidance of endotracheal intubation)

Guillian-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute, autoimmune polyneuropathy. The usual presentation is symmetrical, ascending paralysis evolving over hours to a few days. The legs are usually more affected than the arms. Lower cranial nerves are also frequently involved, causing bulbar weakness and difficulty in maintaining an airway and handling secretions. Deep tendon reflexes also attenuate or disappear within a few days of onset. 

Other options:

Option A: Type IV respiratory failure occurs due to hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles during shock. Intubation and mechanical ventilation can cause a redistribution of cardiac output to vital organs.

Option B: Type III respiratory failure results from lung atelectasis. It is more common in the postoperative period. Treatment includes frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright positioning, and control of incisional and/or abdominal pain. Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.

Option C: Type I respiratory failure (acute hypoxemic type) occurs due to alveolar flooding (caused by alveolar haemorrhage, pulmonary oedema, lung injury, pneumonia) and subsequent ventilation-perfusion mismatch and intrapulmonary shunt physiology. Examples: Sepsis, COVID-19, Gastric aspiration, pneumonia, near-drowning.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presented with fever and retro-orbital pain for 2 days. The tourniquet test and NS1 antigen test were positive. Which of the following is true regarding this infectious disease?

choices.text: Enclosed spaces with air conditioning can increase the transmission of the virus
A maculopapular rash appears on the first day of infection
The vesicular rash begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities and the face from days 3-5
Epistaxis and petechiae can be seen in uncomplicated dengue in the absence of warning signs

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with fever, retro-orbital pain, positive tourniquet test, and NS1 antigen test is suggestive of dengue fever.  In patients infected with dengue virus, epistaxis and petechiae can be seen in uncomplicated cases in both the absence or presence of warning signs.

Dengue is an acute febrile disease caused by the mosquito-borne dengue viruses, consisting of four serotypes (DENV 1 to 4), belonging to the Flaviviridae family. Dengue virus is transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti or "tiger" mosquitoes. Enclosed spaces with air conditioning inhibit the transmission of the dengue virus (option A). The extrinsic incubation period, the time required for the virus to develop inside the mosquito is 8-10 days. The intrinsic incubation period, the time period between entry of the virus in man and the development of the symptoms, is 3–14 days.

Classical dengue fever begins with an abrupt onset of high fever. A macular rash may appear on the first day (option B). The condition is self-limiting though debilitating with headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, petechiae rash, and leucopenia.  A macular-papular recovery rash appears 3–5 days after the onset of fever, and it usually starts on the trunk before spreading peripherally (option C). 

Dengue fever is sometimes referred to as ‘break bone fever’ due to associated severe muscle and joint pain or ‘seven-day fever’ since the symptoms usually persist for 7 days.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies.

questions.text: A patient with a known history of peptic ulcers comes with hematemesis. The urea breath test is positive. The patient's gastric biopsy is taken, and the slide is shown below. The patient is at the highest risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and gastric biopsy showing curved bacteria filling the lumen of a gastric foveola is indicative of Helicobacter pylori infection. This patient is at the highest risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma.

H. pylori is a gram-negative bacillus that lives in gastric mucus and duodenum. It is acid-resistant and motile due to its spiral shape and flagella.

H. pylori is a known risk factor for peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, gastric adenocarcinoma, and gastric lymphoma. However, the risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma is much more than the risk of developing gastric lymphoma.

Many studies have shown H. pylori is protective against peptic esophageal diseases, including esophageal adenocarcinoma and GERD. It is due to H. pylori-induced hypochlorhydria. 

Diagnosis of H. pylori is by:

  • Tests based on endoscopic biopsy - biopsy urease test, histology, and culture of the biopsy specimen.
  • Non-invasive tests - 13C Urea breath test and stool antigen test is useful for follow-up after treatment. H. pylori contains an enzyme called urease. It splits urea into carbon dioxide and ammonium ions. In urea breath test, 13C is ingested by the patient. If H. pylori is present, the urease activity generates 13C-labeled CO2 that then can be detected in the patient’s exhaled breath.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) presents to the emergency room with fever, headache, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. MRI is done for the patient, which is given below. What is the standard treatment for the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of seizures in a patient with HIV and the MRI showing multiple ring-enhancing lesions suggest a diagnosis of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin is the standard treatment in this patient. 

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. It is caused by Toxoplasma gondii. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

Clinical manifestations include altered mental status, seizures, weakness, cerebellar signs, meningismus, cranial nerve manifestations, etc.

The diagnosis is usually based on the MRI findings of multiple lesions in multiple locations. However, a single lesion may also be present. These lesions are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, which show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes, an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring called the eccentric target sign, which is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is usually present.

Differential diagnosis: Other conditions having single or multiple enhancing mass lesions in the HIV-infected patient include

  • Primary CNS lymphoma
  • TB, fungal or bacterial abscesses. 

Treatment:

  • Standard treatment is sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 
  • Alternative regimens are clindamycin + pyrimethamine, atovaquone + pyrimethamine, and azithromycin +pyrimethamine + rifabutin.

Prophylaxis:

  • Primary prophylaxis is to prevent the first occurrence of the toxoplasmosis infection, given to patients with IgG antibodies to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL. A single double-strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given. The same regimen also offers primary protection against Pneumocystis jirovecii. 
  • Secondary prophylaxis/ maintenance therapy is to prevent the recurrence of toxoplasmosis infection if CD4+ T cell counts are <200/μL. Sulfadiazine/ pyrimethamine and leucovorin are given. Secondary prophylaxis is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are >200/μL for 6 months.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with a history of frequent infections, fatigue, headaches and blurring of vision. On examination, he has lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests show normocytic normochromic anaemia and a positive Coombs test, with serum electrophoresis revealing a sharp spike of monoclonal IgM. Which of the following is true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Treatment is initiated in the disease irrespective of the presence of symptoms
Best responses to ibrutinib are observed in patients with mutated MYD88 and mutated CXCR4
Control of serious hyperviscosity symptoms can be achieved acutely by plasmapheresis
Alkylating drugs are one of the first-line therapy for asymptomatic patients

questions.solution:
The patient has classic symptoms due to hyperviscosity, like headache and blurring of vision, and has a spike of monoclonal IgM. The most likely diagnosis is Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia. In this condition, control of serious hyperviscosity symptoms can be achieved acutely by plasmapheresis.

Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia is a plasma cell disorder that increases memory B cell proliferation. These cells produce large amounts of IgM, leading to the classic hyperviscosity syndrome. 

Treatment is usually initiated only when the disease causes symptoms (option A) or leads to severe anaemia, hyperviscosity, lymphadenopathy, or hepatosplenomegaly. Plasmapheresis can provide quick relief for serious symptoms caused by hyperviscosity, such as altered confusion or weakness, since about 80% of the IgM protein is found in the blood vessels.

For patients with symptomatic Waldenström's Macroglobulinemia (option D), the first-line treatments are BTK inhibitors (ibrutinib), alkylating drugs (bendamustine and cyclophosphamide), and proteasome inhibitors (bortezomib, carfilzomib, andixazomib). These treatments may be given alone or more commonly, combined with rituximab. Ibrutinib specifically targets the constantly active BTK protein. Among patients who have already received one type of treatment, 91% responded positively to ibrutinib. The best responses to ibrutinib occur in patients with a specific mutation in the MYD88 gene and a normal CXCR4 gene (option B). Patients with a mutated CXCR4 gene tend to have slower and lower response rates to ibrutinib.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs has not been found to reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF?

HFrEF: heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, DHP-type calcium channel blockers such as amlodipine have no role in the management of HFrEF and do not reduce mortality due to it. 

Heart failure is a complex clinical syndrome that occurs because the ventricle is unable to fill with or eject blood. The important etiologies of heart failure include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and high output states, such as beriberi, thyrotoxicosis, and severe anaemia.

Patients with heart failure complain of dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. On examination, pedal oedema, elevated JVP, ascites, and hepatomegaly may be present.

Heart failure is termed HFrEF when the EF is below 40%. The pharmacological management of HFrEF includes two broad categories of drugs:

Drugs with symptomatic and mortality benefits reduce mortality in patients by neurohormonal mechanisms and thus prevent cardiac remodelling. These drugs include:

  • Angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI): a combination of sacubitril (neprilysin inhibitor) and valsartan (angiotensin-receptor blocker)
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors: ramipril, enalapril
  • β-blockers: metoprolol, carvedilol, bisoprolol
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist: spironolactone, eplerenone
  • Sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors (SGLT2 inhibitor) - dapagliflozin
  • Hydralazine plus isosorbide dinitrate: has shown mortality benefit only in African-American patients

Drugs with symptomatic benefits are used only when there are specific indications for their use or when the patient has decompensation of already existing heart failure.

  • Loop diuretics such furosemide
  • Digoxin

Non-pharmacological therapy for HFrEF includes implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICD) and cardiac resynchronization therapy.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation presented with acute, severe abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting. She had one episode of bloody stools. Examination reveals hypoactive bowel sounds and mild abdominal distension. Which of the following investigations is likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of atrial fibrillation, severe abdominal pain, bloody stools, and hypoactive bowel sounds, is likely to have acute mesenteric ischemia. The investigation likely to confirm the diagnosis is CT angiography.

Acute mesenteric ischemia occurs when there is an imbalance between splanchnic perfusion and intestinal metabolic demand. The three causes of mesenteric ischemia are:

  • Arterio-occlusive ischemia
  • Nonocclusive ischemia
  • Mesenteric venous thrombosis. 

This patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which is likely the source of the embolus that led to intestinal ischemia. Other risk factors for arterio-occlusive ischemia are recent myocardial infarction, valvular heart disease, and recent cardiac catheterisation. 

The intestines have widespread collateral formation to reduce the effects of ischemia. However, two areas - Griffith's point (splenic flexure) and Sudeck's point (sigmoid flexure) are areas with decreased blood flow. These areas are the meeting point for collateral vessels and, thus, are most at risk for intestinal ischemia. 

Acute mesenteric ischemia usually presents with severe, acute abdominal pain that is out of proportion to the abdominal examination. There may also be nausea, vomiting, transient diarrhoea, anorexia, and bloody stools. There may also be mild abdominal distension and hypoactive bowel sounds. 

The gold standard for diagnosis is CT angiography. If it is acute, angiography can be done during the laparotomy as it is an emergency condition. Treatment involves resection of the dead bowel and restoring blood flow. 

Other options: 

Option A - Abdominal X-ray will reveal gas under the diaphragm in case of hollow viscous perforation. However, this finding is non-specific and can occur in any abdominal viscus perforation. 

Option C - Cardiac enzymes will be elevated in myocardial infarction. This patient has mesenteric ischemia. 

Option D - An electrocardiogram may help rule out acute myocardial infarction and for diagnosing atrial fibrillation in this case. It would not confirm a diagnosis of mesenteric ischemia.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of weakness, weight loss, diarrhea, oily stools, and joint pain for about 6 months.  A diagnosis of malabsorption syndrome was suspected. A duodenal biopsy was done, and the findings are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea, weight loss, and chronic arthralgia and the given slide showing macrophages filled with PAS-positive inclusions points to a diagnosis of Whipple's disease.

Whipple's disease is a multi-system disease caused by infection with gram-positive bacillus Tropheryma whipplei. Clinical features include arthralgia and arthritis, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Arthralgias and arthritis are present for many years before the appearance of GI symptoms. CNS involvement is common and presents as psychiatric manifestations, memory problems, or ophthalmoplegia. Dementia may occur in later stages. Cardiac involvement may be in the form of endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis. Hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas may also be seen. Intermittent low-grade fever is present in most of the patients.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is primarily established by endoscopic biopsy and histological evaluation. Infiltration of lamina propria with PAS-positive macrophages containing the bacilli is diagnostic. The remainder of the cases are diagnosed by PCR, which can be done on duodenal biopsies or fluids (such as CSF and synovial fluid) or tissues.

The treatment regimen for Whipple's disease is ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks, followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months. Prolonged antibiotics are recommended, but there is still uncertainty prevailing regarding the optimal regimen.

Other options:

Option B: Celiac disease presents as a malabsorption syndrome due to the immune response to gluten in the diet. It is characterized by the presence of IgA antigliadin, anti-endomysial, and anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Histology will show a flat appearance of the intestine epithelium with crypt hyperplasia and villous atrophy. There is also an increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes and increased numbers of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the lamina propria. The image below shows the intestinal biopsy of a patient with celiac disease.

Option C: Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious etiology. It is predominantly seen in some tropical countries such as India. It is usually preceded by an episode of acute gastroenteritis. Small bowel biopsy resembles that of celiac disease. Treatment is with broad-spectrum antibiotics and folic acid.

Option D: Bacterial overgrowth causes deconjugation of bile acids and their deficiency in the lumen of the small intestine. This causes malabsorption, leading to diarrhea with steatorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not applicable to rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis?

choices.text: Hyperglycemia is a major risk factor
CT scan is used for definitive diagnosis
Cavernous sinus thrombosis is seen in advanced cases
Liposomal amphotericin B is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
CT scan is not used for the definitive diagnosis of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. The investigation of choice, in this case, is an endoscopic biopsy followed by histopathological examination.

The most accurate site for such biopsies is the middle turbinate. Histopathological analysis of the biopsy sample will reveal characteristic hyphal findings of the fungus causing mucormycosis. Rhizopus is the most commonly implicated organism in mucormycosis. 

CT scans of the head and sinuses do not yield findings that are specific for mucormycosis (indistinguishable from those seen in bacterial sinusitis). This makes it an ineffective investigation of choice. 

Other options

Option A - Hyperglycemia is a major risk factor in mucormycosis. It disrupts normal iron sequestration and phagocytic action and promotes tissue penetration of the fungus. This effect is compounded in states of diabetic ketoacidosis. 

Option C - Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is characterised by complications such as cavernous sinus thrombosis when advanced cases are encountered. Clinical features suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis are bilateral proptosis, chemosis, vision loss, and impairment of extraocular muscle function (ophthalmoplegia). 

Option D - Mucormycosis is primarily managed by the administration of a polyene antifungal drug. The liposomal formulation of amphotericin B (LAmB) is the drug of choice in CNS infections. It has proven efficacy due to good penetration. The initial dosage is 5 mg/kg per day, and it can be escalated to 7.5-10 mg/kg per day.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was referred to a haematologist following symptoms of easy bruising and recurrent epistaxis.  Further workup revealed JAK-2 mutations. Identify the true statement regarding this condition:

choices.text: Hemoglobin level of >16 g/dL in women is diagnostic
Associated with lower risk of thrombotic events
High levels of serum erythropoietin is seen

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with JAK2 mutations on workup, is indicative of polycythemia vera (PV). The true statement regarding this condition is that a haemoglobin level of >16 g/dL in women is diagnostic.

PV is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which phenotypically normal red cells, granulocytes, and platelets accumulate in the absence of a recognisable physiologic stimulus.

It is common among women before the fifth decade of life, and the most common cytogenetic abnormality in PV is the JAK2 mutation. 

Clinical features of polycythemia vera include easy bruising, epistaxis, acid-peptic disease, or gastrointestinal haemorrhage due to vascular stasis or thrombocytosis. Systolic hypertension and neurologic symptoms such as vertigo, tinnitus, headache, visual disturbances, and transient ischemic attacks (TIA) occur due to erythrocytosis.

In some patients, venous or arterial thrombosis involving cerebral, cardiac, or mesenteric vessels may be seen. Intra-abdominal venous thrombosis is particularly common in young women and maybe catastrophic if a sudden and complete obstruction of the hepatic vein occurs.

Patients also complain of aquagenic pruritus, where they have generalised itching following a warm bath or a shower. On examination, there is splenomegaly and lab reports reveal elevated haemoglobin, hematocrit, and red blood cell counts.

Diagnostic criteria for PV: 

  • Major criteria - 
    • Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men and >16 g/dL in women or hematocrit of >49% in men and 48% in women
    • Bone marrow biopsy - hypercellularity with trilineage growth (panmyelosis), including prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation
    • Presence of JAK-2 mutation
  • Minor criterion - subnormal erythropoietin levels

A diagnosis of PV requires all three major criteria or the first two major and one minor criterion.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice bulbous swelling in his toes, as seen in the image below. A similar finding is not noted in his fingers. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
Since the given image shows clubbing involving the toes and the fingers are spared, the patient has differential clubbing. Therefore, he is likely to have patent ductus arteriosus.

Differential clubbing refers to the clubbing of toes but not of the fingers. It is a rare sign that indicates patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with Eisenmenger syndrome.

In COPD, there is no clubbing. In case there is clubbing in a patient with COPD, then the possibility of lung cancer must be ruled out.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterised by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Patent ductus arteriosus (causes differential clubbing)
    • Aortic aneurysm (infected abdominal aortic aneurysm can also cause differential clubbing)
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing:

  • Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas, in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window is obliterated. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

questions.text:
A young woman delivered a baby at 34 weeks of gestation due to abruptio placenta. After four days of delivery, she developed bleeding from venipuncture sites, petechiae, and ecchymoses over her body. The lab findings and the peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb- 12 mg/dL
WBC count- 10000/cu. mm
Platelet count- 90,000/μL
Prothrombin time- 17s
Activated partial thromboplastin time: 47 s
Elevated fibrin degraded products
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

DIC is characterised by widespread intravascular fibrin formation. The most common causes are bacterial sepsis, obstetric causes (abruptio placenta, amniotic fluid embolism), and malignancies like acute promyelocytic leukaemia.

Exposure of blood to phospholipids from damaged tissue, hemolysis, and endothelial damage leads to the exposure of tissue factors and the generation of thrombin. Thrombin generation leads to fibrin deposition in the small blood vessels, activation of coagulation factors, and consumption of platelets.

Patients will have bleeding manifestations due to decreased platelet counts. The most common findings are bleeding ranging from oozing from venipuncture sites, petechiae, and ecchymoses to severe haemorrhage from the gastrointestinal tract, lung, or central nervous system.

Laboratory investigations in DIC

  • Decreased platelet count 
  • Prolonged prothrombin time PT/TT
  • Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
  • Elevated fibrin degradation products (D-dimers)
  • Peripheral smear shows schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells) 

Other options

Option A- Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is the autoimmune destruction of the platelets. It may be primary or may occur secondarily due to autoimmune disorders, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and infections, such as HIV and hepatitis C. They will also have a low platelet count. However, a peripheral smear may show large platelets with otherwise normal morphology.

Option B- Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is characterised by pentad- microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA), thrombocytopenia, neurologic symptoms, fever, and renal failure. The pathophysiology of TTP involves the accumulation of ultra-large multimers of von Willebrand factor as a result of decreased activity of the plasma proteases. These multimers cause MAHA. The coagulation tests are normal, and fibrin-degraded products are not elevated.

Option D- Factor V is normally inactivated by protein C. Factor V Leiden mutation results in resistance to the inactivation by protein C. This leads to abnormally high levels of factor V, leading to thrombosis. The patients may have thromboses like deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary thrombosis.

questions.text:
A male patient came with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and irritability for a few weeks. He was on antitubercular drugs for the past 1 month. The laboratory investigations are given below. The most likely diagnosis is :
  • Hemoglobin - Reduced
  • Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) - Reduced
  • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) - Raised
  • Serum ferritin - Raised
  • Serum iron - Raised
  • Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) - Normal
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is sideroblastic anemia. 

The following are the points given in the question pointing to this diagnosis: 

  • Symptoms of anemia - fatigue, weakness
  • History of taking anti-tubercular drugs (isoniazid)
  • Laboratory investigations showing - reduced MCH, raised MCV, raised serum iron, raised serum ferritin, and normal TIBC 

Isoniazid has a pyridoxine antagonistic action, which results in defective heme synthesis. Pyridoxine acts as a cofactor of the aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthetase enzyme, which is the rate-limiting enzyme in heme synthesis. Isoniazid-induced sideroblastic anemia is a rare condition due to defective heme synthesis.

Sideroblastic anemia is a group of disorders characterized by the presence of sideroblasts. Sideroblasts are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing non-heme siderotic granules and stain Prussian blue positive. Based on etiology, sideroblastic anemia is classified into hereditary and acquired types.

Hereditary sideroblastic anemia: 

It is an X-linked disorder caused by a defect in the activity of ALA synthetase required for heme synthesis. Affected females act as carriers, but males have moderate to marked anemia, which manifests in childhood or early adulthood.

Acquired sideroblastic anemia: This is further divided into - 

1) Primary acquired/idiopathic/refractory - it is regarded as a myelodysplastic disorder in the FAB classification. It occurs in middle-aged and elderly individuals of both sexes. This occurs due to the reduced activity of the ALA synthetase enzyme. This furthermore causes disturbed growth and maturation of the erythroid precursors (hematopoietic stem cells). Anaemia is moderate to severe and appears gradually.

2) Secondary Acquired - may occur secondary to - 

  • Drugs, chemicals, and toxins - isoniazid, alcohol, and lead
  • Hematological disorders - myelofibrosis, acute leukemia, lymphoma, and hemolytic anemia.
  • Miscellaneous - inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus.

Peripheral smear in sideroblastic anemia shows hypochromic microcytic (sometimes normocytic) anemia. MCH and MCV are reduced in the hereditary type and raised in the acquired type. Serum ferritin and serum iron are raised, and TIBC shows complete saturation. Bone marrow examination shows erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts, as shown below.

Pyridoxine for 2-3 months is administered routinely to all cases of sideroblastic anemia. Blood transfusion and other supportive therapy may be required. In cases of secondary sideroblastic anemia, the primary focus is the removal of the offending agent.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary pathology of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis leads to the destruction of the exocrine pancreas and not the endocrine pancreas.

The destruction of the endocrine pancreas is secondary to the destruction of the exocrine pancreas. It occurs with progressive fibrosis of the pancreas and is one of the sequelae of primary pathology. 

Cystic fibrosis:

  • Autosomal recessive exocrinopathy affects multiple epithelial tissues.
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator[CFTR]- serves as an anion channel in the apical membranes of epithelial cells and regulates the volume and composition of exocrine secretion.
  • A Defect in the gene results in thick, hyper-viscous exocrine secretions, which lead to the primary pathologies seen in cystic fibrosis.

Disease manifestations include:

  • Respiratory-  copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions obstruct small and medium-sized airways, leading to respiratory compromise. Bacterial flora (including Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa) is routinely cultured from CF sputum.
  • Pancreas- Thick and adherent exocrine secretions obstruct pancreatic ducts and impair the production and flow of digestive enzymes. There is tissue destruction of the exocrine pancreas, with fibrotic scarring, cyst proliferation, and loss of acinar tissue.
  • Hepatic- Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis leading to hepatic insufficiency and multilobular cirrhosis.
  • GIT- of the intestinal lumen is often difficult to excrete, leading to meconium ileus in newborns and distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in adults.
  • Infertility- (i)Males- developmental abnormality secondary to improper secretion by the vas or associated structures leading to complete involution of the vas deferens and infertility. About 99% of males with CF are infertile (ii)Females-  abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions lead to an increased incidence of infertility
  • Sinusitis- occurs in most CF patients

questions.text: A 78-year-old female presents with atrial fibrillation. She is a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 10 years. What is her CHA2DS2-VASc score?

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients who have atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation therapy is given when the score is ≥2. Patients with a score of 1 may also be considered for anticoagulation therapy.

Anticoagulation therapy is given for all patients of AF having mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or a history of stroke.

In the given case (CHA2DS2-VASc score = 5), oral Warfarin can be initiated to reduce stroke risk. If bleeding occurs, anticoagulation can be reversed by administering vitamin K or clotting factors. Echocardiography revealed mitral regurgitation and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following ECG findings is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presentations of chest tightness and collapsing after the marathon, along with a similar family history, with echocardiography revealing mitral regurgitation and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet, suggest hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). Among the given options, a tall T wave in an ECG is not a finding seen in HOCM.

Left ventricular hypertrophy, left axis deviation, and prominent Q wave are associated with HOCM.

HOCM is the leading cause of sudden death in young. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by predominant diastolic dysfunction presenting as exercise intolerance. 

The patients have a dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction due to septal hypertrophy and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet (SAM). SAM leads to mitral regurgitation with the jet directed posteriorly. It is characterized by misalignment of the enlarged myofibrils and myocytes.

The ventricular cavity is banana-shaped in HOCM, as seen on echocardiography. The murmur of HOCM is an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. 

ECG-findings include:

  • Prominent abnormal Q waves
  • P wave abnormalities
  • Left axis deviation
  • Deeply inverted T waves 

Echocardiography:

  •  LV wall thickness ≥15 mm
  • Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve
  • LVOT obstruction

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to your clinic due to recurrent episodes of cough productive of large amounts of sputum for 2 years. She is a non-smoker. Lung examination reveals wheezes with crackles bilaterally. A transverse section of the CT lung is given in the image below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: CT of chest shows tram-track appearance
Surgical resection of the affected organ forms the mainstay of management
It can be caused by aspiration of foreign body
Poor mucociliary clearance is one of the mechanisms of pathogenesis

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with the CT scan showing the signet ring sign is diagnostic of bronchiectasis. Surgical management of this condition is considered in only select cases and does not form the mainstay of treatment.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of bronchi due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired mucociliary clearance (e.g. impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. Focal bronchiectasis can be caused due to the pressure effects of a foreign body or tumor or neighboring lymphadenopathy on the airway.

Clinically, patients present with persistent productive cough and production of thick tenacious sputum. On examination, there will be clubbing, wheezing, and crackles.

A chest X-ray shows a tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. Chest CT is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. 

CT findings include

  • Tram-track appearance
  • Signet-ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

The image given below shows the signet ring sign (arrows) seen in bronchiectasis:

Management includes antibiotic therapy, improved secretion clearance, bronchial hygiene, and anti-inflammatory therapy.

Surgery is only indicated in select cases where the bronchiectasis is confined to a single lobe or segment. Lung transplantation is considered in severe bronchiectasis cases, predominantly when associated with cystic fibrosis. In a case of bronchiectasis presenting with massive hemoptysis, intubation is done to stabilize the patient, the source of bleeding is identified, and the nonbleeding lung is protected. Bronchial artery embolization is often needed to control the bleeding.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic with a chronic dry, nagging cough associated with weakness and fatigue for 1 year. He has worked in the stone-cutting industry for 20 years and complains that his efficiency at work has decreased drastically over the years. On examination, his vitals are stable. His chest x-ray shows bilateral eggshell calcification in the hilar region.  Histopathology of the lung shows the following.  Which of the following is the patient at increased risk for, compared to the general population?
questions.solution:
The clinical, radiological and histopathological features in this patient are suggestive of Silicosis. It causes pulmonary alveolar macrophage dysfunction, and hence, patients with silicosis have a higher risk of developing lung infections from organisms like M. Tuberculosis, atypical mycobacteria, and fungi.

In this scenario, the key features suggestive of silicosis are:

  • A man who has worked in the stone-cutting industry (exposure to silica) for 20 years (long-term exposure)
  • Symptoms of chronic dry, nagging cough
  • CXR findings of eggshell calcification
  • Histological findings of silicotic nodules characterised by concentrically arranged hyalinised collagen fibres surrounding an amorphous centre in the hilar lymph nodes and the upper zones of the lungs.

Other options:

Pleural effusion, bronchogenic carcinoma, and mesothelioma are associated with asbestosis.

Asbestosis - X-ray shows peripheral reticular opacities predominantly in the lower zones. HRCT shows subpleural fibrotic lines, irregular opacities, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Risk of bronchogenic carcinoma > mesothelioma in asbestosis.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with CD4 count < 50/μL complaints of fever, weight loss and night sweats. Which of the following investigations would you order to confirm an atypical mycobacterial infection?

choices.text: Cartridge based nucleic acid amiplification test

questions.solution:
Infection with  Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is confirmed by blood culture. 

MAC is an atypical mycobacterial infection commonly seen in HIV-infected patients, most commonly in those with CD4 count < 50/μL, presenting with fever, weight loss and night sweats. Chest X-ray may show bilateral lower lobe infiltrates, alveolar infiltrates, and mediastinal adenopathy. Diagnosis is made by blood culture or two positive sputum cultures.

As per NACO guidelines, routine prophylaxis is not recommended in India. Pharmacotherapy for MAC infection is with Clarithromycin or Azithromycin + Ethambutol. 

Other Options:

CBNAAT, IFN-𝛄 assay and BAL can all be used to diagnose M. tuberculosis but not MAC. On the other hand, blood culture is not used to diagnose M. tuberculosis.

questions.text: A patient with fatigue was found to have hepatomegaly on examination. The JVP waveform is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given JVP waveform shows the presence of C-V waves — the merging of the C and V waves of JVP, without proper x descent. This is a feature of tricuspid regurgitation.

Other physical findings that may be seen in tricuspid regurgitation include hepatomegaly with systolic pulsations, peripheral edema, and positive hepatojugular reflux. All these findings are due to the volume overload on the right side of the heart. 

A prominent RV pulsation in the left parasternal may be seen, along with a holosystolic murmur on the lower left sternal margin.
