questions.text: A young man presents to the hospital with complaints of profuse diarrhea for the past 2 days. He says that he had been to Goa and had tried seafood and shellfish. There is no fever. He says that the stool appears watery and gray. The result of the test is shown in the image below. What is the antibiotic of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the test are suggestive of cholera infection. The test shown in the above image is the String test performed to identify the colonies of Vibrio cholerae. Erythromycin and azithromycin are the antibiotics of choice in this patient.

Cholera is a diarrheal disease caused by Vibrio cholerae serogroup O1 or O139. It is commonly acquired by eating contaminated water and shellfish. The incubation period is around 24- 48 hours. 

Patients may be asymptomatic or have only mild diarrhea. Others present with the sudden onset of explosive and life-threatening diarrhea (cholera gravis). They usually complain of sudden onset of painless watery diarrhea which can become voluminous. It is associated with vomiting. Fever is usually absent. 

The stool has a characteristic appearance. It appears gray, slightly cloudy fluid with flecks of mucus, no blood, and has a fishy odor. It has been called a “rice-water” stool because it resembles the water in which rice has been washed.

The selective media of the organism is as taurocholate–tellurite–gelatin (TTG) agar or thiosulfate–citrate–bile salts–sucrose (TCBS) agar.

Treatment involves rehydration with oral rehydration solution or ringer's lactate. Erythromycin and azithromycin are the antibiotic agents of choice.

Other options:

Option A- Ciprofloxacin is used in the treatment of shigellosis. The patient may have a fever, abdominal cramps, and bloody mucopurulent stools.

Option C- Streptomycin is used in the treatment of brucellosis. It is a zoonotic disease and is caused by exposure to infected animals or their products. It can be due to ingestion, inhalation, or mucosal or percutaneous exposure. It presents as a fever with profuse sweating, especially at night.

Option D- Ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of enteric fever. It presents as headache, chills, malaise, arthralgia, abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. On examination, they may have a faint, salmon-coloured, blanching, maculopapular rash located primarily on the trunk and hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient is diagnosed with dengue fever. He developed a saddleback fever. Which of the following is an accurate description of this fever pattern?

choices.text: Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is <0.6 °C
Acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days
Fever lasts for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days
Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is >0.6 °C

questions.solution:
In the saddleback type fever, which is seen in dengue, acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days.

Pel-Ebstein fever is a fever lasting for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days. (option C)

Continuous fever is characterised by the temperature remaining elevated, without touching the baseline, and the fluctuation not exceeding 0.6°C. This type of fever is seen in cases of lobar pneumonia, infective endocarditis, enteric fever, etc.(option A)

Remittent fever is characterised by temperature fluctuations exceeding 0.6°C, but without touching the baseline. (option D)

Relapsing fever is characterized by several days of fever, followed by several days of an afebrile period, after which the cycle repeats (e.g. Borrelia infection and rat-bite fever)

Tertian fever occurs on the first and third days. (e.g. infection with Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, and Plasmodium falciparum)

Quartan fever occurs on the first and fourth days. (e.g. Plasmodium malariae infection)

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory. On examination, his BMI is 41 kg/m2, blood pressure is 160/100 mm of Hg and an apnea-hypopnea index of 7. His awake arterial blood gas analysis is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

HCO3-: 25 mEq/L

PaCO2: 38 mmHg

PaO2: 98 mmHg
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an obese patient with daytime sleepiness with an apnea-hypopnea index of 7 and normal ABG is suggestive of obstructive sleep apnea.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is diagnosed if the patient has either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness and ≥ 5 episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep. This is known as the apnea-hypopnea index and is calculated as number of episodes ÷ number of hours of sleep.

Each such episode should last for at least 10 seconds, resulting in a ≥ 3% drop in oxygen saturation or brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed by overnight polysomnogram (PSG). This includes measurement of breathing, oxygenation, body position, cardiac rhythm, sleep stages, and snoring intensity.

Note that waking hypoxemia or hypercarbia in a patient with OSA suggests cardiopulmonary disease or obesity hypoventilation syndrome (option B).

Narcolepsy (option C) presents with difficulty sustaining wakefulness and disturbed nocturnal sleep. However, unlike sleep apnea, patients with narcolepsy usually feel well-rested on awakening and then feel tired throughout the day. One of the most characteristic clinical features which is seen is cataplexy – sudden muscle weakness without a loss of consciousness, which is usually triggered by strong emotions.

Central sleep apnea (CSA) (option D) is caused due to increased sensitivity to PCO2. This causes an unstable breathing pattern, which manifests as hyperventilation alternating with apnea. Prolonged circulation delay between pulmonary capillaries and carotid chemoreceptors is also a contributing cause. Hence, patients with heart failure may show CSA. They can present with Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of passing reddish-brown colored urine and episodic abdominal pain for the past few months. Reports reveal anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. Flow cytometry shows CD55/CD59-negative RBCs. What is the drug of choice for her condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of intravascular hemolysis due to paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). The drug of choice for treating PNH is Eculizumab. 

Eculizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that has greatly improved the outcome for many patients with PNH from around the world. It works by inhibiting complement C5 which then prevents the activation of the complement cascade, thus preventing intra-vascular hemolysis. 

Supportive management of PNH includes folic acid and iron supplementation. Bone marrow transplantation is another option for the treatment of this condition. 

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is characterized by recurrent intravascular hemolysis that can also be associated with pancytopenia and venous thrombosis. Patients present with complaints of passing blood in urine or anemia. In the case of venous thrombosis, they can present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain.  

The diagnosis of PNH is made by flow cytometry which can be carried out on red blood cells or granulocytes. The cells are CD55 or CD59 negative.

Other options:

Option A: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal murine antibody that targets VEGF-A and thereby inhibits vascular proliferation and tumor growth. It is used in colorectal cancer.

Option B: Tocilizumab is an IL-6 receptor antagonist, used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

Option D: Abciximab is the Fab fragment of a humanized monoclonal antibody directed against glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. It is administered to patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention. It prevents recurrent myocardial infarction and death when used in conjunction with aspirin and heparin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of tuberculosis presents with dyspnea on exertion. On examination, it is noted that the JVP rises during inspiration. A chest radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of tuberculosis now presenting with positive Kussmaul's sign and pericardial calcification seen on the chest radiograph suggests a diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis. 

Constrictive pericarditis is a chronic type of pericarditis that results when there is healing of acute fibrinous pericarditis or absorption of chronic pericardial effusion. While the most common cause in developing countries is tuberculosis, in developed countries, it occurs following viral pericarditis, cardiac surgery, mediastinal irradiation, or as a manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis and SLE. The main abnormality that occurs in constrictive pericarditis is the inability of the ventricles to fill because of the rigid and thickened pericardium. Unlike tamponade, this restriction is not uniform through the diastole. Ventricular filling is normal early in the diastole but stops suddenly when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. Y-descent on the JVP curve is prominent in constrictive pericarditis because it represents the rapid early filling of the ventricles. A sudden stop in ventricular filling and subsequent rising pressure is seen as a square root sign in the JVP curve.

The patient presents with exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. There may be a paradoxical rise in venous pressure during inspiration (Kussmaul's sign). Apart from constrictive pericarditis, Kussmaul's sign can be positive in tricuspid stenosis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, right heart failure, and pulmonary embolism. The ECG often shows low-voltage QRS complexes and diffuse flattening of T-waves. A chest radiograph may show pericardial calcification, especially in tuberculous pericarditis.

questions.text: A young patient with asthma currently not on any treatment reports that he experiences symptoms once a week and no nighttime awakenings. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment strategy for him?

choices.text: Inhaled corticosteroids plus formoterol when needed

questions.solution:
Presence of daytime symptoms only once a week and the absence of any nighttime symptoms points to a diagnosis of intermittent asthma in this patient. The most appropriate treatment strategy for him would be inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and formoterol when needed. 

Patients with intermittent asthma were treated with a short-acting β2-receptor agonist such as salbutamol as a reliever medication. However, chronic airway inflammation is present even in patients with intermittent asthma and can lead to more severe attacks in the future. To tackle this, GINA now recommends the use of low-dose ICS and formoterol combination inhaler when needed even in patients with intermittent asthma. Even though formoterol is a long-acting β2-receptor agonist, its onset of action is quick and it provides quick symptom relief to the patient.

Asthma is categorized as intermittent if the patient has daytime symptoms up to 2 times per week, and nighttime awakenings due to symptoms up to 2 times per month. If the symptoms are more severe than this, then the patient's asthma is categorized to be persistent. Persistent asthma is further divided into the following based on the severity of the symptoms:

Mild persistent More than 2 times per week but less than daily 3-4 times a month but not every week

Low dose ICS + formoterol as needed
Moderate persistent Daily Once per week Low dose ICS + formoterol daily
Severe persistent Present throughout the day along with severe restriction of daily activities Almost every night Medium to high dose ICS + formoterol/LABA daily + add-on drugs

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a high fever and abdominal pain for the past 2 days. He has a history of inflammatory bowel disease. His abdominal radiograph is shown below. Identify the true statements regarding his condition.
  1. It is a common complication of Crohn's disease.
  2. It is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon, with a diameter of >6 cm.
  3. It can be triggered by electrolyte abnormalities and narcotics.
  4. Emergency colectomy is indicated in patients in cases of failed medical therapy.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the radiograph showing a dilation of the colon with loss of haustral folds is suggestive of a toxic megacolon. Statements 2, 3, and 4 correspond with the diagnosis of toxic megacolon.

Toxic megacolon is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon to a diameter of more than 6 cm. It is a rare complication and is associated with severe ulcerative colitis. It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics as they interfere with gut motility. 

It may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Bacterial infection with features of sepsis may also be seen. It can result in perforation. 

Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations.

It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, and bowel rest) and medical therapy, which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

The clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhoea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Investigations show it elevated C-reactive protein, platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, faecal calprotectin, and faecal lactoferrin. A colonoscopy reveals loss of typical vascular pattern, granularity, and ulceration in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns. Barium contrast enema shows a lead pipe appearance characterised by a smooth-walled colon with complete loss of haustrations.

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD:

  • Episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis
  • Erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of the clinical course of a patient admitted to the medicine ward with a fever. Which of the following would not be seen in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical course shown in the given image is suggestive of leptospirosis. Conjunctival suffusion is a feature of leptospirosis, not conjunctivitis. Conjunctival suffusion refers to the redness of eyes without inflammation, which would be seen in conjunctivitis.

The image shows leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease with two phases of illness after an incubation period of around 20 days. The organism can be present in the blood, CSF, or urine, depending on the phase of the illness. Leptospirosis is caused by contact with the urine or blood of an infected organism. It is a zoonosis and can affect all mammalian species; rats are well-known reservoirs. 

Illness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. Clinical distinction between the 2 phases may not be seen, as shown by the overlap of phases in the graph.

  • Acute leptospiremic phase - the organism can be cultured from blood, as seen in the graph.
  • Resolving immune phase - the organism can be cultured from urine. Antibodies can be detected using a microscopic agglutination test. 

Fever, conjunctival suffusion (red-eye), jaundice, relative bradycardia (Faget sign), and meningeal signs (neck rigidity and Kernig's sign positive) are features of leptospirosis.

Most cases are asymptomatic. However, a few may present with severe manifestations called Weil's disease, which is a triad of bleeding, jaundice, and acute kidney injury.

Diagnosis:

  • Microscopy -
    • Examination of blood - Leptospires may be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence. The organism disappears from the blood after 1 week.
    • Examination of urine: Leptospires appear in the urine in the second week of the disease. Centrifuged deposits of the urine may be examined under dark ground illumination.
  • Culture - With semisynthetic media like Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris (EMJH) medium or Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media.
  • Serotype-specific tests: 
    • Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)
    • Macroscopic agglutination test  
    • A rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospira-specific IgM antibody in human sera.

The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally, given once a week, is effective in prophylaxis.

questions.text:
A researcher conducted a study on the association of various risk factors with obstructive sleep apnea. Which of the following is false regarding the risk factors of OSA?

OSA - obstructive sleep apnea

choices.text: The prevalence of OSA is two-fold higher among men than among women
Postmenopausal women are at increased risk compared to premenopausal women
The prevalence of OSA is especially high among patients with diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
OSA has a strong genetic association, illustrated by its significant familial aggregation and heritability. For first-degree relatives of individuals with OSA, the odds of developing the condition are approximately twice as high compared to those without affected relatives.

The major risk factors for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) include obesity, male sex, and older age. Other contributing factors are mandibular retrognathia and micrognathia, a family history of OSA, a sedentary lifestyle, genetic syndromes that impair upper airway function (such as Down syndrome and Treacher-Collins syndrome), adenotonsillar hypertrophy—especially in children—menopause in women, and various endocrine disorders like acromegaly and hypothyroidism. Approximately 40–60% of OSA cases are linked to excess weight. Obesity contributes to OSA by causing upper airway fat to narrow the pharyngeal lumen.

The prevalence of OSA is about twice as high in men as in women (option A). Factors that increase men's risk for OSA include an android pattern of obesity, which leads to fat deposition in the upper airway and abdomen, as well as a relatively longer pharynx, which increases the likelihood of collapse during sleep. Premenopausal women tend to be relatively protected from OSA due to the influence of sex hormones on their ventilatory drive (option B).

The prevalence of OSA varies with age, affecting 5 to 15% of middle-aged adults and more than 20% of elderly individuals. It is particularly high among patients with certain medical conditions, including diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation (option D).

questions.text: A patient who was in a road traffic accident and sustained an open fracture of the femur one hour ago was transfused with 3 units of PRBC. Two hours later, he developed hypotension, hypoxia, dyspnea, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI).

TRALI is a sudden onset of respiratory failure resulting from the transfusion of donor fresh frozen plasma and platelets that contain high-titer of anti-HLA antibodies. These antibodies bind recipient leukocytes and aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature, releasing mediators that increase capillary permeability. 

The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
  • Second hit - the aggravating factor (most commonly MHC class II  antibodies) present in the transfused blood product activates the primed neutrophils

TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. Recipients with a history of pre-existing lung diseases, smoking, chronic alcohol use, mechanical ventilation and cancer surgeries are at increased risk of developing TRALI. 

The recipient develops symptoms of hypotension, fever, hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates visible on the chest x-ray.

Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae. The incidence of TRALI has been reduced by choosing males and nulliparous women as donors.

Other options:

Option A: Anaphylaxis is characterized by dyspnea, hypotension, rash, and stridor due to bronchospasm, and pulmonary edema and chest infiltrate are not seen.

Option C: Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) is caused by rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products. This condition is characterized by dyspnea, systolic hypertension, and cardiogenic pulmonary edema causing bilateral infiltrates on chest x-rays (elevated brain natriuretic peptide). It can be prevented by administering the transfusion slowly and treated with diuretics if necessary.

Option D: Hemolytic transfusion reaction may present with fever, chills, hypotension, tachycardia, dyspnea, chest and back pain, hemoglobinuria, and hemoglobinemia. In the most severe cases, DIC, acute renal failure, shock, and death may occur.

questions.text:
Match the following heart sounds to the disorders they are seen in.
1. Ejection click and ejection systolic murmur A. Bicuspid aortic valve
2. Ejection click only B. Mitral stenosis
3. Late systolic murmur C. Aortic stenosis
4. Opening snap and diastolic murmur D. Mitral valve prolapse
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

1. Ejection click and ejection systolic murmur

C. Aortic stenosis
2. Ejection click only

A. Bicuspid aortic valve
3. Late systolic murmur

D. Mitral valve prolapse
4. Opening snap and diastolic murmur B. Mitral stenosis
  • In aortic stenosis, the opening of the stenosed valve produces an ejection click prior to the ejection systolic murmur.
  • In the bicuspid aortic valve, the click is prominent, but there is no murmur.
  • Mitral stenosis is characterised by an opening snap in the diastole followed by a mid-diastolic murmur. The closer the opening snap is to the S2, the worse the prognosis in mitral stenosis.
  • A late systolic murmur heard best at the apex, indicates Mitral valve prolapse.
